notes: Reply to automated AI survey - explicitly says "I know this is an automated message"

messages.body:
Customer Name,

I know this is an automated message, but I wanted to reach out anyway. Iâ€™ve
been a product manager for over 20 years and a self-described "geek" long
before that. While Iâ€™ve dabbled in PHP, HTML, and CSS for WordPress sites,
Iâ€™ve never been a coder who builds from scratchâ€”the barrier to entry for
creating production-ready software was always too high for someone with my
schedule and family commitments.

However, "vibe coding" with AI has changed everything. I started with
Lovable and have since moved on to using OpenCode (best) and Cursor
(Antigravity is too flaky). Iâ€™ve been able to build extremely useful tools
and websites for my small family business, and with the integration of
GitHub and Vercel, the deployment process essentially takes care of itself.

Iâ€™m interested in staying current with these self-work tools, but I'm also
fascinated by what this means for the profession of software development.
As a product leader, my job spans business & vision vision, through
ideation, and to prod. We are seeing the removal of the primary bottleneck:
the cost and time associated with manual software production and
maintenance. For example, I recently used Codex 5.2 to add a complex 3D
modeling feature to an internal app for my wifeâ€™s business. I simply spoke
the requirements, and it handled the documentation, UI integration, and
database updates instantly.

In my career, that kind of update would have taken weeks or months of PRDs,
release planning, and architectural compromises. I have also seen cycle
times of years. Now, I can move from an idea to a preview environment in
minutes. The speed of iterationâ€”which Agile and SAFe could never solveâ€”is
finally here because we are no longer limited by manual syntax entry by
devs.

I followed you after seeing a recommendation from Theo at T3, specifically
regarding your agents.md article. The idea that "best practices" are now
prompts (or just conversations) rather than rigid frameworks is a massive
shift. Even if the AI doesn't get it right the first time, the cost of
iterating five different versions is lower than the cost of a single
planning meeting.

Software development is having its "horse to engine" moment. And what this
means beyond just software development as well.
Best regards,

Customer Name

notes: Reply to AI interest survey - sharing professional journey and interests

messages.body:
Customer Name,



Yeah, your TypeScript content has been genuinely useful over the yearsâ€”those short videos on generics finally made things click.



Iâ€™ve been watching your AI Hero pivot with interest. Similar trajectory hereâ€”I recently created an â€œAI Customer Nameâ€ role for myself at Aflac after realising AI was changing how I work.



What interests me most:

Context engineeringâ€”the gap between AI that occasionally helps and AI that consistently delivers. Iâ€™ve been building systems that accumulate knowledge across development sessions.



Multi-agent coordinationâ€”orchestrating specialised agents for different development phases. The coordination problem is where it gets interesting.

Evaluationâ€”how do you actually measure if your AI setup is improving? Currently building harnesses to test different context configurations.



What I want to learn more about: how to drive adoption. Part of my role is educating engineers in my organisation and building confidence with AI tools. Youâ€™ve done this at scale with TypeScriptâ€”curious whatâ€™s worked for you in getting developers past the initial scepticism.



Barry



Sent from my iPhone

messages.body:
Customer Name,

I want to learn how to effectively use AI to boost my productivity and get
more stuff done. I donâ€™t like it when AI does everything by itself but
rather use it like a co-coder to facilitate my own work. This might be due
to the complexity of processes and products iâ€˜m working on - AI just isnâ€˜t
there yet.
Please focus on web technologies and workflows that are already well
established. Bleeding edge tech is interesting but of no real use if itâ€˜s
going to be replaced in a year.

Cheers,
Tim

messages.body:
BartÅ‚omiej Wojcieszek has accepted this invitation.

Turn AI Customer Name Customer Name Engineers with Ralph
Customer Name 11, 2026 â‹… 9am â€“ 1pm
Customer Name - Customer Name



Half-day live workshop â€¢ February 11, 9 AM PST â€¢ Limited to 40 developers â€¢ ğŸ‰ **{percentOff}% off** â€” Sale ends ! Only  left.Customer Name  technique runs AI agents in loops with structured PRDs and feedback mechanisms. It's real, it's working in production, and you'll build it today.Customer Name figured out the pattern. Customer Name validated it with people shipping code. The technique has a nameâ€”Ralph (yeah, like Customer Name from Customer Name, because of course it does)â€”and developers are using it right now to clear their GitHub backlogs while they sleep.You're going to learn exactly how to build it.Interactive, hands-on, real code running on YOUR backlog by 1 PM.Here's the thing about AI coding agents right nowYou've tried them. Claude, ChatGPT, Cursor, whatever.You ask for Feature A. You get half a solution. You manually fix it. You ask for Feature B. It breaks Feature A. You're back to debugging. The cycle never ends.You're still doing the engineer's job. The AI is just doing grunt work.But here's what's actually happening right now, today, in production:Developers are setting up agents that run in loops. They point them at GitHub backlogs. The agents execute tasksâ€”real tasks, not toy examplesâ€”and create working PRs. Without constant human intervention. Without hallucinating broken code into existence.This isn't theory. This is happening.The question is: Are you going to keep manually prompting AI and hoping it works? Or are you going to learn the systematic technique that actually makes this autonomous?Customer Name SpotWhy this works now (and didn't before)Two things changed:1. The models got good enoughOpus 4.5 and GPT 5.2 can execute complex tasks if you structure them right. They're not perfect, but they're finally smart enough to work in loops with proper feedback.2. The technique maturedThis isn't about better prompting. It's about:Running agents in loops (not one-shot prompts)Structuring PRDs so agents understand the task breakdownBuilding feedback mechanisms (types, tests, browser validation) so agents catch their own mistakesLetting the loop run until the agent self-corrects instead of you fixing everything manuallyWhen you combine capable models with this systematic approach, you get something that actually looks like autonomous execution.Not magic. Not perfect. But real, usable leverage.How we'll learn this: together, live, step-by-stepYou'll be:Debugging real code on screen with Matt. When something breaks (and it will), we'll figure it out together. Live.Hooking up Ralph directly to your tools. You'll connect the loop to a GitHub backlog and see real PRs getting created.Asking your questions in real-time and getting answers immediately. Not a forum post you check in 3 days. Right there, right then.Working in groups. You'll be mob programming in groups of 2-3, bouncing ideas off each other and learning collaboratively.By 1 PM, you'll have a Ralph setup that works for YOU.A blog post can explain concepts. A video can show you a demo. But neither can debug YOUR specific setup when your bash loop fails, or answer "what happens if I structure my PRD THIS way?" immediately, or show you how other developers in the workshop are solving the same problems you're hitting.That's what you're paying for. Immediate answers to your specific problems.What you're going to learn (and build)This is a half-day workshop. Four hours. Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Customer Name, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundationâ€”once it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lieâ€”you'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessingâ€”it's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just executeâ€”it validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Customer Name Customer Name Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manuallyâ€”it's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually executeâ€”not theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

Customer Name, big fan of your TS work. Been trying to get into AI and was happy
and bummed out to find your AI Hero site some weeks ago. Happy because you
are a great instructor but bummed because I missed the second cohort by a
few days (I'm assuming there was a first one which I therefore missed) and
now the event about Ralph sold out in just a few hours... Man I'm so sad...
I don't want to miss out on the opportunity to learn all you have to
teach... Please, tell me, are you planning to repeat the cohorts/events in
the future? Again, big fan of your work, thanks.

notes: Reply to AI interest survey with skepticism about Ralph

messages.body:
Customer Name. I am very aware of who you are - I've paid for your courses (I
think the mailing list should give it away lol), and follow you on LinkedIn
and YouTube.

I am a front-end swe at Google. Formerly at Dialogflow and Firebase, now at
Customer Name. I currently contribute to the Customer Name UI.

I want to learn how others are using AI and how I can improve or tweak my
ever evolving daily workflows. I am very skeptical of this Ralph concept
(not your course). I hope I can make it off the waitlist, enroll in a
future course, or pay for a recorded version. My skepticism of Ralph stems
from the excessive jargon and word salad in Customer Name's post
<https://ghuntley.com/ralph/> and some YouTube interviews. I am absolutely
certain I will learn something from your course and it will be time and
money well spent, but the Ralph concept feels very snake oily. Isn't this a
very temporary problem? Is a standard solution
<https://venturebeat.com/orchestration/mits-new-recursive-framework-lets-llms-process-10-million-tokens-without>
to the context rot issue far off?

Can't Gemini and Customer Name with MCP do this out of the box? Did the blog
post need to be longer than the first two lines?

*If you've seen my socials lately, you might have seen me talking about
Ralph and wondering what Ralph is. Ralph is a technique. In its purest
form, Ralph is a Bash loop.*



*```while :; do cat PROMPT.md | claude-code ; done```*

Anyway, I was hoping the course would prove me wrong and that I'd gain a
new trick or two. I am especially interested in seeing how agents are
orchestrated and your approach to writing PRDs. Also, I'd just love to talk
to other devs to learn/share how LLMs can improve our workflows. For me,
it's mostly on the communication side: writing documents, drafting emails,
preparing for performance reviews, and understanding new [to me] codebases.

Thanks for all you do. I've learned a lot!

Jeff

Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­
Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â­ Â 

Fly.io Newsletter

Hi there,

It's been a minute, but that's because we've been busy working on something pretty fun: Sprites ( https://sprites.dev/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )! They're stateful sandbox environments that you can easily checkpoint and restore. Thomas says they're "ball-point disposable computers," ( https://fly.io/blog/design-and-implementation/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) but whatever you call them, they're probably worth checking out if you're sick of trying to build or test anything in ephemeral sandboxes.

You only pay for the resources you actually consume while running them, but you can kick the tires now with $30 of free credit. Let us know what you build!

Product updates

Customer Name Produce ( https://community.fly.io/c/fresh-produce/27?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) section of our Customer Name is where we update y'all on what's new. There's a lot over there about Sprites, but there's some other important stuff going on, too:

* Postgres 17 is here ( https://community.fly.io/t/you-asked-and-we-shipped-postgres-17-on-mpg/26430?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )! (For people who like shiny new indexes, planner improvements, and general "Postgres got faster again" vibes.)
* The experience of launching an app from the dashboard got a makeover! ( https://community.fly.io/t/launch-your-app-from-the-dashboard-better-ui-heck-yeah/26838?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )

Customer Name

We're excited be able to share Sprites with you, and we're honestly having fun using them ourselves. We ran a lil "show and tell" at our last Customer Name meeting; here are a couple of things that the folks working at Fly.io are building:

* A progressive web app chat UI ( https://github.com/clouvet/sprite-mobile?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) for accessing Customer Name running in YOLO mode on a Sprite, an ideal vibe-coding interface on your phone. It allows input by text, voice, and image, persists sessions across clients, and seamlessly networks with your other Sprites through Tailscale.
* spritessh ( https://github.com/jbellerb/spritessh?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) is a simple bridge so your legacy (anything older than 1 week) tools can use Sprites over plain SSH.
* A project ( https://github.com/symkat/Fly-Workspaces?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ) that provisions code-server to your Sprite so that you can do development work from anywhere you have a web browser, even an iPad!
* Bookworm ( https://bookworm-demo-v53c.sprites.app/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io ): A 100% vibe-coded web app, running on a Sprite, for tracking your book reading list. You can search for books and add them to your list (powered by the Customer Name API) or add them manually, then mark them as started/finished reading.

Feature story

We'd normally do a whole thing here, diving into the background of what Sprites are and how they were designed, but Kurt and Thomas wrote quite a few words on those topics already, so we'll send you straight to the source:

* What are Sprites, exactly? ( https://fly.io/blog/code-and-let-live/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )
* Customer Name & Implementation of Sprites ( https://fly.io/blog/design-and-implementation/?utm_campaign=Jan+%2725+Newsletter&utm_content=Email&utm_medium=email_action&utm_source=customer.io )

Thoughts/comments/cool stuff you've spun up on Sprites since you started reading this two minutes ago? You know where to find us. (On the other side of this newsletter! Just hit "reply.")

Thanks,

Customer Name.io Team

Customer Name ( https://track.customer.io/manage_subscription_preferences/dgSN7QkDAMWyRMSyRAGb5093BVbNPOU14sKobfk= ) ãƒ»

messages.body:
Just a quick progress update: me and Joel had a chat about plans for this
year and I'm thinking a simple plan works best:

Plan is to do *four cohorts of new material this year*, dates to be
finalized tomorrow.

First will be Ralph-based, sometime in March, likely around 10 weeks away.

Others I think it makes sense for now to play them by ear and set deadlines
for when we want to solidify the content.

notes: This is an automated calendar acceptance notification from a customer who accepted an invitation to

messages.body:
Customer Name has accepted this invitation.

Turn AI Customer Name Customer Name Engineers with Ralph
Customer Name 11, 2026 â‹… 9am â€“ 1pm
Customer Name - Customer Name



Half-day live workshop â€¢ February 11, 9 AM PST â€¢ Limited to 40 developers â€¢ ğŸ‰ **{percentOff}% off** â€” Sale ends ! Only  left.Customer Name  technique runs AI agents in loops with structured PRDs and feedback mechanisms. It's real, it's working in production, and you'll build it today.Customer Name figured out the pattern. Customer Name validated it with people shipping code. The technique has a nameâ€”Ralph (yeah, like Customer Name from Customer Name, because of course it does)â€”and developers are using it right now to clear their GitHub backlogs while they sleep.You're going to learn exactly how to build it.Interactive, hands-on, real code running on YOUR backlog by 1 PM.Here's the thing about AI coding agents right nowYou've tried them. Claude, ChatGPT, Cursor, whatever.You ask for Feature A. You get half a solution. You manually fix it. You ask for Feature B. It breaks Feature A. You're back to debugging. The cycle never ends.You're still doing the engineer's job. The AI is just doing grunt work.But here's what's actually happening right now, today, in production:Developers are setting up agents that run in loops. They point them at GitHub backlogs. The agents execute tasksâ€”real tasks, not toy examplesâ€”and create working PRs. Without constant human intervention. Without hallucinating broken code into existence.This isn't theory. This is happening.The question is: Are you going to keep manually prompting AI and hoping it works? Or are you going to learn the systematic technique that actually makes this autonomous?Customer Name SpotWhy this works now (and didn't before)Two things changed:1. The models got good enoughOpus 4.5 and GPT 5.2 can execute complex tasks if you structure them right. They're not perfect, but they're finally smart enough to work in loops with proper feedback.2. The technique maturedThis isn't about better prompting. It's about:Running agents in loops (not one-shot prompts)Structuring PRDs so agents understand the task breakdownBuilding feedback mechanisms (types, tests, browser validation) so agents catch their own mistakesLetting the loop run until the agent self-corrects instead of you fixing everything manuallyWhen you combine capable models with this systematic approach, you get something that actually looks like autonomous execution.Not magic. Not perfect. But real, usable leverage.How we'll learn this: together, live, step-by-stepYou'll be:Debugging real code on screen with Matt. When something breaks (and it will), we'll figure it out together. Live.Hooking up Ralph directly to your tools. You'll connect the loop to a GitHub backlog and see real PRs getting created.Asking your questions in real-time and getting answers immediately. Not a forum post you check in 3 days. Right there, right then.Working in groups. You'll be mob programming in groups of 2-3, bouncing ideas off each other and learning collaboratively.By 1 PM, you'll have a Ralph setup that works for YOU.A blog post can explain concepts. A video can show you a demo. But neither can debug YOUR specific setup when your bash loop fails, or answer "what happens if I structure my PRD THIS way?" immediately, or show you how other developers in the workshop are solving the same problems you're hitting.That's what you're paying for. Immediate answers to your specific problems.What you're going to learn (and build)This is a half-day workshop. Four hours. Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Customer Name, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundationâ€”once it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lieâ€”you'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessingâ€”it's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just executeâ€”it validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Customer Name Customer Name Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manuallyâ€”it's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually executeâ€”not theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

messages.body:
Customer Name/AI Hero team,

Excited for the course! I have a few questions below so that I'm best prepared:

> What you need to bring Technical requirements:
>
> - GitHub account with a repo you can work on

Does this repo need to be public, or can it be private work-related?
Better if my repo is full-stack, front-end, or back-end?
Any other guidance on the repo (which programming language, webapp or mobile app, etc.) for the smoothest 4 hours? I have flexibility and am asking because I'll be creating the repo for the course.

> - Any one of these AI coding CLIs installed and working:
>
> - Customer Name (Opus 4.5)
> - OpenCode
> - Copilot CLI
> - Codex (GPT 5.2)

Do you always stick with a specific agent while Ralphing? With my legacy pre-Ralph HITL Cursor AI ways, I would find even the smartest agents (Opus 4.5 and GPT 5.2) can struggle or hit a dead-end while the other smart agent can sometimes quickly solve, so at times I flip agents. Perhaps you never encountered this, or perhaps those clear PRDs of yours make the problem far less or non-existant.

Thanks!
Jon

triggerMessage.body:
Customer Name/AI Hero team,

Excited for the course! I have a few questions below so that I'm best prepared:

> What you need to bring Technical requirements:
>
> - GitHub account with a repo you can work on

Does this repo need to be public, or can it be private work-related?
Better if my repo is full-stack, front-end, or back-end?
Any other guidance on the repo (which programming language, webapp or mobile app, etc.) for the smoothest 4 hours? I have flexibility and am asking because I'll be creating the repo for the course.

> - Any one of these AI coding CLIs installed and working:
>
> - Customer Name (Opus 4.5)
> - OpenCode
> - Copilot CLI
> - Codex (GPT 5.2)

Do you always stick with a specific agent while Ralphing? With my legacy pre-Ralph HITL Cursor AI ways, I would find even the smartest agents (Opus 4.5 and GPT 5.2) can struggle or hit a dead-end while the other smart agent can sometimes quickly solve, so at times I flip agents. Perhaps you never encountered this, or perhaps those clear PRDs of yours make the problem far less or non-existant.

Thanks!
Jon

The technique has a nameâ€”Ralph (yeah, like Customer Name from Customer Name, because of course it does)â€”and developers are using it right now to clear their GitHub backlogs while they sleep.You're going to learn exactly how to build it.Interactive, hands-on, real code running on YOUR backlog by 1 PM.Here's the thing about AI coding agents right nowYou've tried them. Claude, ChatGPT, Cursor, whatever.You ask for Feature A. You get half a solution. You manually fix it. You ask for Feature B. It breaks Feature A. You're back to debugging. The cycle never ends.You're still doing the engineer's job. The AI is just doing grunt work.But here's what's actually happening right now, today, in production:Developers are setting up agents that run in loops. They point them at GitHub backlogs. The agents execute tasksâ€”real tasks, not toy examplesâ€”and create working PRs. Without constant human intervention. Without hallucinating broken code into existence.This isn't theory. This is happening.The question is: Are you going to keep manually prompting AI and hoping it works? Or are you going to learn the systematic technique that actually makes this autonomous?Customer Name SpotWhy this works now (and didn't before)Two things changed:1. The models got good enoughOpus 4.5 and GPT 5.2 can execute complex tasks if you structure them right. They're not perfect, but they're finally smart enough to work in loops with proper feedback.2. The technique maturedThis isn't about better prompting. It's about:Running agents in loops (not one-shot prompts)Structuring PRDs so agents understand the task breakdownBuilding feedback mechanisms (types, tests, browser validation) so agents catch their own mistakesLetting the loop run until the agent self-corrects instead of you fixing everything manuallyWhen you combine capable models with this systematic approach, you get something that actually looks like autonomous execution.Not magic. Not perfect. But real, usable leverage.How we'll learn this: together, live, step-by-stepYou'll be:Debugging real code on screen with Matt. When something breaks (and it will), we'll figure it out together. Live.Hooking up Ralph directly to your tools. You'll connect the loop to a GitHub backlog and see real PRs getting created.Asking your questions in real-time and getting answers immediately. Not a forum post you check in 3 days. Right there, right then.Working in groups. You'll be mob programming in groups of 2-3, bouncing ideas off each other and learning collaboratively.By 1 PM, you'll have a Ralph setup that works for YOU.A blog post can explain concepts. A video can show you a demo. But neither can debug YOUR specific setup when your bash loop fails, or answer "what happens if I structure my PRD THIS way?" immediately, or show you how other developers in the workshop are solving the same problems you're hitting.That's what you're paying for. Immediate answers to your specific problems.What you're going to learn (and build)This is a half-day workshop. Four hours. Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Customer Name, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundationâ€”once it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lieâ€”you'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessingâ€”it's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just executeâ€”it validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Customer Name Customer Name Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manuallyâ€”it's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually executeâ€”not theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

Turn AI Customer Name Customer Name Engineers with Ralph
Customer Name 11, 2026 â‹… 9am â€“ 1pm
Customer Name - Customer Name



Half-day live workshop â€¢ February 11, 9 AM PST â€¢ Limited to 40 developers â€¢ ğŸ‰ **{percentOff}% off** â€” Sale ends ! Only  left.Customer Name  technique runs AI agents in loops with structured PRDs and feedback mechanisms. It's real, it's working in production, and you'll build it today.Customer Name figured out the pattern. Customer Name validated it with people shipping code. The technique has a nameâ€”Ralph (yeah, like Customer Name from Customer Name, because of course it does)â€”and developers are using it right now to clear their GitHub backlogs while they sleep.You're going to learn exactly how to build it.Interactive, hands-on, real code running on YOUR backlog by 1 PM.Here's the thing about AI coding agents right nowYou've tried them. Claude, ChatGPT, Cursor, whatever.You ask for Feature A. You get half a solution. You manually fix it. You ask for Feature B. It breaks Feature A. You're back to debugging. The cycle never ends.You're still doing the engineer's job. The AI is just doing grunt work.But here's what's actually happening right now, today, in production:Developers are setting up agents that run in loops. They point them at GitHub backlogs. The agents execute tasksâ€”real tasks, not toy examplesâ€”and create working PRs. Without constant human intervention. Without hallucinating broken code into existence.This isn't theory. This is happening.The question is: Are you going to keep manually prompting AI and hoping it works? Or are you going to learn the systematic technique that actually makes this autonomous?Customer Name SpotWhy this works now (and didn't before)Two things changed:1. The models got good enoughOpus 4.5 and GPT 5.2 can execute complex tasks if you structure them right. They're not perfect, but they're finally smart enough to work in loops with proper feedback.2. The technique maturedThis isn't about better prompting. It's about:Running agents in loops (not one-shot prompts)Structuring PRDs so agents understand the task breakdownBuilding feedback mechanisms (types, tests, browser validation) so agents catch their own mistakesLetting the loop run until the agent self-corrects instead of you fixing everything manuallyWhen you combine capable models with this systematic approach, you get something that actually looks like autonomous execution.Not magic. Not perfect. But real, usable leverage.How we'll learn this: together, live, step-by-stepYou'll be:Debugging real code on screen with Matt. When something breaks (and it will), we'll figure it out together. Live.Hooking up Ralph directly to your tools. You'll connect the loop to a GitHub backlog and see real PRs getting created.Asking your questions in real-time and getting answers immediately. Not a forum post you check in 3 days. Right there, right then.Working in groups. You'll be mob programming in groups of 2-3, bouncing ideas off each other and learning collaboratively.By 1 PM, you'll have a Ralph setup that works for YOU.A blog post can explain concepts. A video can show you a demo. But neither can debug YOUR specific setup when your bash loop fails, or answer "what happens if I structure my PRD THIS way?" immediately, or show you how other developers in the workshop are solving the same problems you're hitting.That's what you're paying for. Immediate answers to your specific problems.What you're going to learn (and build)This is a half-day workshop. Four hours. Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Customer Name, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundationâ€”once it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lieâ€”you'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessingâ€”it's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just executeâ€”it validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Customer Name Customer Name Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manuallyâ€”it's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually executeâ€”not theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

messages.body:
Customer Name Workspace has accepted this invitation.

Turn AI Customer Name Customer Name Engineers with Ralph
Customer Name 11, 2026 â‹… 9am â€“ 1pm
Customer Name - Customer Name



Half-day live workshop â€¢ February 11, 9 AM PST â€¢ Limited to 40 developers â€¢ ğŸ‰ **{percentOff}% off** â€” Sale ends ! Only  left.Customer Name  technique runs AI agents in loops with structured PRDs and feedback mechanisms. It's real, it's working in production, and you'll build it today.Customer Name figured out the pattern. Customer Name validated it with people shipping code. The technique has a nameâ€”Ralph (yeah, like Customer Name from Customer Name, because of course it does)â€”and developers are using it right now to clear their GitHub backlogs while they sleep.You're going to learn exactly how to build it.Interactive, hands-on, real code running on YOUR backlog by 1 PM.Here's the thing about AI coding agents right nowYou've tried them. Claude, ChatGPT, Cursor, whatever.You ask for Feature A. You get half a solution. You manually fix it. You ask for Feature B. It breaks Feature A. You're back to debugging. The cycle never ends.You're still doing the engineer's job. The AI is just doing grunt work.But here's what's actually happening right now, today, in production:Developers are setting up agents that run in loops. They point them at GitHub backlogs. The agents execute tasksâ€”real tasks, not toy examplesâ€”and create working PRs. Without constant human intervention. Without hallucinating broken code into existence.This isn't theory. This is happening.The question is: Are you going to keep manually prompting AI and hoping it works? Or are you going to learn the systematic technique that actually makes this autonomous?Customer Name SpotWhy this works now (and didn't before)Two things changed:1. The models got good enoughOpus 4.5 and GPT 5.2 can execute complex tasks if you structure them right. They're not perfect, but they're finally smart enough to work in loops with proper feedback.2. The technique maturedThis isn't about better prompting. It's about:Running agents in loops (not one-shot prompts)Structuring PRDs so agents understand the task breakdownBuilding feedback mechanisms (types, tests, browser validation) so agents catch their own mistakesLetting the loop run until the agent self-corrects instead of you fixing everything manuallyWhen you combine capable models with this systematic approach, you get something that actually looks like autonomous execution.Not magic. Not perfect. But real, usable leverage.How we'll learn this: together, live, step-by-stepYou'll be:Debugging real code on screen with Matt. When something breaks (and it will), we'll figure it out together. Live.Hooking up Ralph directly to your tools. You'll connect the loop to a GitHub backlog and see real PRs getting created.Asking your questions in real-time and getting answers immediately. Not a forum post you check in 3 days. Right there, right then.Working in groups. You'll be mob programming in groups of 2-3, bouncing ideas off each other and learning collaboratively.By 1 PM, you'll have a Ralph setup that works for YOU.A blog post can explain concepts. A video can show you a demo. But neither can debug YOUR specific setup when your bash loop fails, or answer "what happens if I structure my PRD THIS way?" immediately, or show you how other developers in the workshop are solving the same problems you're hitting.That's what you're paying for. Immediate answers to your specific problems.What you're going to learn (and build)This is a half-day workshop. Four hours. Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Customer Name, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundationâ€”once it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lieâ€”you'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessingâ€”it's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just executeâ€”it validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Customer Name Customer Name Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manuallyâ€”it's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually executeâ€”not theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

The cycle never ends.You're still doing the engineer's job. This is happening.The question is: Are you going to keep manually prompting AI and hoping it works? Or are you going to learn the systematic technique that actually makes this autonomous?Customer Name SpotWhy this works now (and didn't before)Two things changed:1. The models got good enoughOpus 4.5 and GPT 5.2 can execute complex tasks if you structure them right. They're not perfect, but they're finally smart enough to work in loops with proper feedback.2. The technique maturedThis isn't about better prompting. It's about:Running agents in loops (not one-shot prompts)Structuring PRDs so agents understand the task breakdownBuilding feedback mechanisms (types, tests, browser validation) so agents catch their own mistakesLetting the loop run until the agent self-corrects instead of you fixing everything manuallyWhen you combine capable models with this systematic approach, you get something that actually looks like autonomous execution.Not magic. Not perfect. But real, usable leverage.How we'll learn this: together, live, step-by-stepYou'll be:Debugging real code on screen with Matt. When something breaks (and it will), we'll figure it out together. Live.Hooking up Ralph directly to your tools. Immediate answers to your specific problems.What you're going to learn (and build)This is a half-day workshop. Four hours. Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Customer Name, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundationâ€”once it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lieâ€”you'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessingâ€”it's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just executeâ€”it validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Customer Name Customer Name Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manuallyâ€”it's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually executeâ€”not theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lieâ€”you'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessingâ€”it's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just executeâ€”it validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Customer Name Customer Name Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manuallyâ€”it's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually executeâ€”not theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

The technique has a nameâ€”Ralph (yeah, like Customer Name from Customer Name, because of course it does)â€”and developers are using it right now to clear their GitHub backlogs while they sleep.You're going to learn exactly how to build it.Interactive, hands-on, real code running on YOUR backlog by 1 PM.Here's the thing about AI coding agents right nowYou've tried them. Claude, ChatGPT, Cursor, whatever.You ask for Feature A. You get half a solution. You manually fix it. You ask for Feature B. It breaks Feature A. You're back to debugging. The cycle never ends.You're still doing the engineer's job. The AI is just doing grunt work.But here's what's actually happening right now, today, in production:Developers are setting up agents that run in loops. They point them at GitHub backlogs. The agents execute tasksâ€”real tasks, not toy examplesâ€”and create working PRs. Without constant human intervention. Without hallucinating broken code into existence.This isn't theory. This is happening.The question is: Are you going to keep manually prompting AI and hoping it works? Or are you going to learn the systematic technique that actually makes this autonomous?Customer Name SpotWhy this works now (and didn't before)Two things changed:1. The models got good enoughOpus 4.5 and GPT 5.2 can execute complex tasks if you structure them right. They're not perfect, but they're finally smart enough to work in loops with proper feedback.2. The technique maturedThis isn't about better prompting. It's about:Running agents in loops (not one-shot prompts)Structuring PRDs so agents understand the task breakdownBuilding feedback mechanisms (types, tests, browser validation) so agents catch their own mistakesLetting the loop run until the agent self-corrects instead of you fixing everything manuallyWhen you combine capable models with this systematic approach, you get something that actually looks like autonomous execution.Not magic. Not perfect. But real, usable leverage.How we'll learn this: together, live, step-by-stepYou'll be:Debugging real code on screen with Matt. When something breaks (and it will), we'll figure it out together. Live.Hooking up Ralph directly to your tools. You'll connect the loop to a GitHub backlog and see real PRs getting created.Asking your questions in real-time and getting answers immediately. Not a forum post you check in 3 days. Right there, right then.Working in groups. You'll be mob programming in groups of 2-3, bouncing ideas off each other and learning collaboratively.By 1 PM, you'll have a Ralph setup that works for YOU.A blog post can explain concepts. A video can show you a demo. But neither can debug YOUR specific setup when your bash loop fails, or answer "what happens if I structure my PRD THIS way?" immediately, or show you how other developers in the workshop are solving the same problems you're hitting.That's what you're paying for. Immediate answers to your specific problems.What you're going to learn (and build)This is a half-day workshop. Four hours. Each module gives you something you can implement immediately.Section 1: Getting StartedYour own bash loop, not vendor pluginsThe Anthropic plugin doesn't get the best out of Ralph. You're going to run your own bash loop instead.You'll build a working loop on your machine that gives you complete ownership. Works with Customer Name, OpenCode, Codex, or any coding agent CLI you choose. Your infrastructure, your control, your pricing.We'll walk through the exact setup, debug it live if it breaks, and make sure you've got a loop running before we move on.What this unlocks: Everything else. This is your foundationâ€”once it's running, you own the infrastructure and the loop.Section 2: Feedback LoopsHow agents catch their own mistakesHere's the secret: Agents are only as clever as the tools they use to interface with the world. Without feedback, they're coding blind. With the right tools, they can feel their way to working code.For backend: We teach Ralph to do TDD. Red-Green-Refactor is the perfect feedback loop. Write a failing test (Red). Write code until it passes (Green). Clean up (Refactor). The test gives the agent eyes. But tests can lieâ€”you'll learn how to structure PRDs so agents write tests you can actually trust.For frontend: We hook Ralph up to an MCP server that can query the actual UI. The agent can see what's on screen, check if buttons exist, verify layouts rendered correctly. It's not guessingâ€”it's looking.The agent runs, gets feedback, tries again, self-corrects. That's the loop.What this unlocks: Autonomy. Now the agent doesn't just executeâ€”it validates, catches mistakes, and self-corrects.Section 3: Customer Name Customer Name Your BacklogFrom GitHub issues to executed PRsWire an agent to your GitHub backlog so it executes tasks without you.You'll structure your backlog so agents can parse it. Turn issues into agent-executable tasks using the specific pattern that works. Handle agent state and failures gracefully. Review PRs from agents (what to look for, what to ignore, what breaks most often).This is where you'll start seeing actual PRs getting created from your real issues.What this unlocks: Scale. Now you're not running the loop manuallyâ€”it's connected to your backlog.Section 4: Making PRD's Ralph LovesThe skill that makes or breaks agent executionMost people can't write PRDs that agents execute correctly. Too vague? Agent guesses wrong. Too detailed? Agent misinterprets specifics.Here's the framework you'll learn:The 3-Layer PRD Structure:Context layer: What the agent needs to understand about the systemTask layer: The specific change broken into atomic stepsValidation layer: How the agent knows it succeededPlus the interview technique: You'll learn how to get the agent to help you build better PRDs by asking it the right questions about your task.By the end, you'll have written PRDs that agents can actually executeâ€”not theory, actual working examples.Common mistakes that make agents hallucinate or fail:Being too abstract about "what should happen"Not specifying the validation criteriaForgetting to mention dependencies between tasks</l

messages.body:
Customer Name,

Thanks for reaching out. I'm like you also was a part of the TS world for a
long time. Now time has changed and I feel like I'm getting behind with all
AI innovations.
There are a few areas that interest me about AI:

   - Product development - how can AI models/agents/workflows enhance my
   product, how can I make users life easier.
   - Software development lifecycle - how can AI help me to write better
   code and deliver better product features.

I think, in more general terms, I'm interested in understanding how to
design and build AI flows, be it agents or workflows. I'm also interested
in learning how to assess different models to be able to choose one that
suits the use-case best.

I hope it helps.

Cheers,
Anton

It covers core concepts like how AI models work, prompt engineering basics, and common use cases. Work through one module at a time rather than trying to absorb everything at once.

notes: Reply to AI interest survey - excited about Ralph pattern

messages.body:
Customer Name,

I've seen some of your TypeScript vids and lately the one on Ralph. The
Ralph one and other patterns I'm seeing around using specs driven dev with
Claude has what's really made me excited about using AI in a more
controlled way.

I'm interested in getting a more in depth understanding of what's in the
context window (if that's even possible?) so that I can really start to
understand a bit more what's going on under the hood.

Your YT vids are great, you've got a loyal subscriber now :D

Nick

notes: Reply to AI interest survey - sharing perspective on AI hype

messages.body:
Customer Name,

Thanks for reaching out. I've been following your TypeScript work for a
while now.

Regarding AI, there is obviously a lot of reasonable hype right now, but
social media is saturated with rage-bait, exaggerations, and people
misrepresenting what's actually possible just for engagement.

I'm mostly interested in cutting through that noise to find clear,
grounded, and true perspectives on what is really happening in the AI
coding space.

Best,
Javier

notes: Following up on discount request - active billing inquiry

messages.body:
Hey Siva,


That sale discount didn't stack with the PPP discount sorry. The best price for you would be the regionally discounted license. If you pay for a full license you'll get the bonus interviews and access to your license anywhere.

Hi Haze,

Thank you so much for getting back to me and for extending the holiday discountâ€”I really appreciate the gesture.

I ran into a small technical issue when trying to use the link. It seems the checkout system doesn't allow me to combine the holiday code with the India Purchasing Power Parity (PPP) pricing. When I apply the code, it defaults to the global price, which brings the total to $198.

Given my current situation of being out of work for six months, $198 is still quite a high hurdle for me to clear right now.

Is there any way to generate a specific code that applies a further discount to the India regional price, or perhaps a different way to process this so I can get closer to a manageable amount?

Thank you again for your patience and for trying to help me make this work.

Best regards,

Siva

-------- Original Message --------
On Tuesday, 01/13/26 at 04:51 Haze Provinsal <user@example.com> wrote:

> Hey Siva,
>
> The greatest discount you can get Is the PPP discount from India.
>
> But I can still extend the holiday discount for you. This Is valid for a week: https://www.totaltypescript.com/buy?code=ac9a3c2d-f531-4114-b07e-f922306111a6
>
> Best,

Hello!



I'm an aspiring backend dev wanting to master Typescript. I have some backend TS experience, and some years working in Java at a large tech company.



I purchased the Pro Complete series when it was on sale in December, and I'm finally getting around to looking through it more closely. It feels quite a bit over my head currently, and I see one section on React that is not relevant to the work I'll be doing. I'm wondering, from your perspective, how relevant is the rest of the Pro Complete series to a backend-only TS dev (API design/implementation, database connection, etc)? I'm not planning to author any TS libraries, but will likely work for SaaS companies designing and implementing their backends. I'm wondering if the Essentials series will be sufficient for me.



Thanks,

Jack

triggerMessage.body:
Hello!



I'm an aspiring backend dev wanting to master Typescript. I have some backend TS experience, and some years working in Java at a large tech company.



I purchased the Pro Complete series when it was on sale in December, and I'm finally getting around to looking through it more closely. It feels quite a bit over my head currently, and I see one section on React that is not relevant to the work I'll be doing. I'm wondering, from your perspective, how relevant is the rest of the Pro Complete series to a backend-only TS dev (API design/implementation, database connection, etc)? I'm not planning to author any TS libraries, but will likely work for SaaS companies designing and implementing their backends. I'm wondering if the Essentials series will be sufficient for me.



Thanks,

Jack

messages.body:
This quote encapsulates how I feel about software atm:

https://x.com/cramforce/status/2013992385638986138

> The job of the software engineer is changing. How we learn it is not.
I'm more worried about mid-career engineers not adapting rather than the
next generation. The AI-native devs learning engineering now will run leaps
around us old farts

Our job should be to help the mid-career engineers adapt. LOTS of useful
content to be made there.

I like this insight a lot, great north star here.

Curious if there are any specific attributes that you think come along with
mid-career. I'm gonna avoid leading the question, so if it's not clear
lemme know ;)


-Alex

ğŸ“™  my book: tiny.mba
ğŸ¤  my community: indyhall.org
ğŸ“ˆ  my 10 year goal: 10k.city

Yeah def stuff like that, trying to get a clearer picture of their pain
thru this lens.

Someone mid career could be at FAANG, a large real estate tech company, or
a funded startup. Those folks have different appetites for risk, for new
stuff (passing fad vs here to stay), etc.

If it's helpful to ramble into a camera and share what you're seeing out in
the field that would be super helpful for really dialing this in!
